Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that only South Koreans have Covid-19 antibodies, ignoring the fact that antibodies have been found in people from various countries.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no information or evidence provided to support the assertion that only South Koreans have Covid-19 antibodies.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by suggesting that the presence of Covid-19 antibodies is exclusive to South Koreans, without considering the possibility of antibodies in individuals from other countries.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the presence of Covid-19 antibodies, such as the possibility that antibodies can develop in individuals from different regions.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Covid-19 antibodies have been found in individuals from various countries, as reported by multiple studies.
Understate: The claim may understate the prevalence of Covid-19 antibodies by suggesting that only 60% of the population has antibodies, without considering the possibility of a higher percentage.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting misleading information and failing to provide accurate support for its assertion.
